The benefits to implementing these capabilities well is that computing within and across the multiple tiers enables new applications and features, which can increase efficiency, revenue, and value, and improve the overall experience for the customer.

This white paper examines some of the earlier research by the Edge Fog Consortium, followed by some of the implementation concepts originating in the ETSI standards group, and then concludes with an implementation approach first championed within the TM Forum and now being used to plan smart infrastructure projects surrounding combined telecommunications and electric power distribution as well as transportation, public safety, manufacturing, and  applications.

As has been researched extensively by the Open Fog Consortium, the Industrial Internet of Things Consortium, the European Telecommunications Standards Institute, and the Tele Management Forum, the evolution of smart infrastructure is now maturing and needs to add “smartness” within and across more network tiers as human pursuits continue to expand in meaningful ways on the Earth.

As has been researched extensively by the Open Fog Consortium, the Industrial Internet of Things Consortium, the European Telecommunications Standards Institute, and the Tele Management Forum, the evolution of smart infrastructure is now maturing and needs to add “smartness” within and across more network tiers as human pursuits continue to expand in meaningful ways on the Earth.

That has relatively recently given rise to cloud computing and a return to a centralization of network intelligence in large computing data centers, which then drove the need to provide more sensitive controls close to “things” at remote locations that connect them to the cloud to reduce latency and improve efficiency.

Scale – the plethora of billions of smart elements operating at the edge needing unique circumstantial support outstripping the ability to simplify actions where micromanagement is just not feasible because of the complexity and pure size of the mathematical combinations of considerations.

The original data, detected issue, and the immediate initiated response can be passed along to other potentially more centralized network intelligence centers in parallel for further processing, but the key Is that the critical initial response at the edge is not delayed in the meantime.
Localization of data and computation can improve privacy, security, reliability, resilience, and safety, which, taken together, comprise trustworthiness.

It is a critical architecture for today’s connected world as it enables low latency, reliable operation, and removes the requirement for persistent cloud connectivity to address emerging use cases in Internet of Things (IoT), 5G, Artificial Intelligence (AI), Virtual Reality and Tactile Internet applications.
It is important to note that cloud and fog computing are on a mutually beneficial, inter-dependent continuum.

However, the bandwidth to transport the sensor and actuator data to and from the cloud could cost thousands of dollars per month; those connections could be susceptible to hackers; it may take several hundred milliseconds to react to an abnormal sensor reading, during which time a major leak could spill significant oil; and if the connection to the cloud is down or the cloud is overloaded, control is lost.
In that same scenario, if a hierarchy of local fog nodes is placed near the pipeline, they can connect to sensors and actuators with inexpensive local networking facilities.

Platform as a service (PaaS) is a category of cloud computing services that provides a platform allowing customers to develop, run, and manage web applications without the complexity of building and maintaining the infrastructure typically associated with developing and launching an application.

This architecture is applicable across many different markets including, but not limited to, transportation, agriculture, smart-cities, smart–buildings, healthcare, hospitality, energy, and financial services.
Manageability: Managing all aspects of fog deployments, which include RAS, DevOps, etc., is a critical aspect across all layers of a fog computing hierarchy.

In synchronization with the thinking coming out of the Open Fog Consortium, the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) has generated some more specific recommendations towards implementation of this new approach to tiered smart infrastructure that provides ideas on the implementation focused on guidance for mobile operators.

The vocabulary coming from ETSI for this concept is the Multi-access Edge Computing  (“MEC”) discussion (which is why we are using this term for continuity) and it will draw the next wave of investments by Mobile operators who want to take advantage of low latency services that 5G promises - which means running services closer to the consumers (that is close to radio sites).
On the left side you see the servers that are turned into virtualized infrastructure, while on the right site is VIM that manages virtual resources on top of these servers.

The beauty of MEC ETSI architecture is that MEC Apps are network-aware (so that MEC Apps can act based on that) and that is where MEC Service can help by exposing the network information through APIs.

The new vision for the MEC spans and automates the compute and connectivity product and service catalog configuration requirements for fulfilment from Cloud to Edge and for operations from Edge back to Cloud incorporating appropriate use of private edge / on device, on premise, far edge, near edge through to public cloud.

The MEC will enable Vertical Product Managers to easily add their application services and solutions, such as AI and Digital Twins and then easily define, offer, sell, fulfill, manage and bill complex bundled solutions which include multi-sourced partner offerings for target markets, such as SMB, Smart Airports, Smart Agriculture, or Smart City etc.

In addition to just the physical nodes that provide the resources for the tiered environment, the MEC has a logical architecture associated with providing for the Platform as a Service for microservices running in the nodes, but it also provides for the horizontal services needed to provide the management of the distributed systems environment as well as the cybersecurity elements needed to protect the remote computation nodes.

For the convenience of simplifying the implementation of the tiers, a common pattern is used for supporting the tiered distributed applications and microservices pods and containers, as well as the elements that provide for the traditional needs of a distributed systems environment.

DDS has a feature of allowing the creation of domains such that all local events can be sequestered into just the one node for the most part, and then only those events that need to be used for internodal communications are allowed to travel outside of the node to the next node.
Now, within each container running in the pod environment, there will be a microservice that can be used to subscribe to various “topics” that are associated with the different DDS messages.

But a distributed logging service like the AnyLog technique operates like a very large sharded database on a massively parallel processing supercomputer where the initial data gathering step and intermediate analysis is performed at the edge as opposed to a central computer.

As such, there is a continuing need to have a “Rosetta Stone” form of ontological mapping capability in any event communications facility such as we are discussing for dealing with both the syntax of messages and the semantic meaning of the data itself in the incoming and outgoing communications.

The public cloud is still a very important aspect of the overall system of systems, but it needs to be used for its typical uses and then be augmented by the virtual supercomputer sharded approach at the edges to solve the latency and network traffic problem.

As we examine the details a little more closely, the subfunctions begin to decompose into subsystems on the management side as shown in the diagram below, and the agent functions begin to decompose into rings of security for defense in depth purposes.

The concept of the distribution is to establish a secure private slice network for the distribution, but then use an intelligent delivery process that stages the distributions in a bit of a multicast approach using the spine for broadcasting the containers down into their appointed nodes using a waterfall sequence, position them for smoke testing and field integration testing, and then wait for activation using a blue/green swap technique.

The assembly and testing of delivered containers is done using Infrastructure as Code in which the configuration control involves not only just variables, but also actual scripts that control the assembly process as well as the testing process that accompanies each step of the operation.

As this model is used in actual implementations across multiple industries, the lessons learned need to be accumulated so that the model can be dynamically updated for easier use and to speed the proliferation of the technique as a part of the global public and private networking capability.
